para.text: This shows how to reproduce the first example from the SUTRA 4.0 documentation. In it, a 4m x 4m contaminated zone is surrounded on two sides by a frozen wall and on a third size by the edge of the model in order to isolate the contaminated zone. The model is simulated with a 2D areal model. The following table shows the model properties and how those properties are implemented in ModelMuse

para.text: [here set to a constant density of 1000. kg/m3]

liquid saturation at which minimum relative permeability occurs (SLRKMIN)

para.text: west boundary condition for fluid mass balance
east boundary condition for fluid mass balance
east and west boundary conditions for energy balance
insulated (energy enters via the western inflow and exits via the eastern outflow)
Start model and select a 2D areal model with Freezing Transport. Select the model area to encompass the area where the mesh will be located.

image.title: Screen capture of the ModelMuse Initial Model Area dialog box with 2D areal and Freezing transport selected.
image.caption: Screen capture of the ModelMuse Initial Model Area dialog box with 2D areal and Freezing transport selected.

para.text: The mesh is 25 m long in the X direction and 15 m wide in the Y direction. The mesh elements are square and the distance between nodes is 0.25 m. To create the mesh, select

and draw a quadrilateral over the mesh area. In the Fishnet Mesh Quadrilaterals dialog box, set the coordinates to cover the correct area. Set the discretization to 60 in the Y direction and to 100 in the X direction. Select

image.title: Screen capture of the Fishnet Quadrilateral Properties dialog box showin the quadrilateral corner coordinates
image.caption: Screen capture of the Fishnet Quadrilateral Properties dialog box showin the quadrilateral corner coordinates

image.title: Screen Capture of ModelMuse showing the discretization in the X and Y directions.
image.caption: Screen Capture of ModelMuse showing the discretization in the X and Y directions.

para.text: There are a number of changes that need to be made in the SUTRA Options dialog box.

li.text: On the Title pane, enter "SUTRA 4.0 - Saturated Groundwater Freezing Example, Containment by Frozen Groundwater Wall."

image.title: Screen capture of the Fluid Properties pane showing the value of DRLDU.
image.caption: Screen capture of the Fluid Properties pane showing the value of DRLDU.

li.text: pane check the check box to simulate production.

para.text: One Region is predefined in the
properties. More could be added if desired. For this model, only one region needs to be defined. Five tabs are present on the
pane. Changes need to be made on two of those panes:

image.title: Screen capture of the Relative Permeability Parameters tab illustrating changes to be made on this tab.
image.caption: Screen capture of the Relative Permeability Parameters tab illustrating changes to be made on this tab.

para.text: The model uses two time schedules. One is the TIME_STEPS schedule required for all SUTRA models. The other is used with the observations. For the TIME_STEPS schedule, set NTMAX to 1000, TIMEL to 360,000,000, TIMEC to 3600, NTCYC to 1, TCMULT to 1.02, TCMIN to 3600, and TCMAX to 2,629,800. The second schedule is named Timed_Obs. Set SCHTYP to Step Cycle, NSMAX to 2100, ISTEPI to 0, ISTEPLto 2100, and ISTEPC to 1.

image.title: Screen capture illustrating the values assigned to the TIME_STEPS schedule.
image.caption: Screen capture illustrating the values assigned to the TIME_STEPS schedule.

image.title: Screen capture illustrating the values assigned to the Timed_Obs schedule.
image.caption: Screen capture illustrating the values assigned to the Timed_Obs schedule.

para.text: dialog box, set NPRINT to 10 and NCOLPR and LCOLPR to 10. For the Node and Element files, print liquid saturation and ice saturation.

image.title: Screen capture of the ModelMuse SUTRA Output Control dialog box showing some items that should be specified in the model.
image.caption: Screen capture of the ModelMuse SUTRA Output Control dialog box showing some items that should be specified in the model.

para.text: In this example, the contaminated zone is represented by a fluid flux boundary with a flux rate of zero. The temperature of the associated flux can be set to any value. The zone should encompass all the nodes for (11,4), through (15,0). Because the flux rate is zero, the boundary does not affect the model results. However, you could set the flux rate to a positive value to see how that would affect the model results. A positive flux rate could represent recharge.

Specified pressures of 0 and 500 are present on the East and West edges of the model respectively. Use straight-line objects to define them. The specified pressure boundary on the West side of the model should have an associated temperature of 5
. The associated temperature of the Eastern boundary can be any value.
The specified temperature boundary is in an L-shaped region upstream (West) and to the North of the contaminated zone with a temperature of -5
. One node separates the specified temperature boundary from the contaminated zone.

image.title: Screen capture of ModelMuse showing the specified temperature boundary colored green.
image.caption: Screen capture of ModelMuse showing the specified temperature boundary colored green.

para.text: Five observation locations are defined. They are located at (5,0), (13,0), (17,0), (21,0), and (25,0). If desired, you can use the node number at the observation location in the observation name. Use the Timed_Obs" sAll the observation formats should be
The InitialPressure and InitialTemperature data sets define the initial conditions for the model. The initial temperature is a uniform 5

°C. The initial pressure varies linearly from 500 at the West end to 0 at the East end. Both can be specified using default formulas in the Data|Edit Data Sets dialog box. One suitable formula for the initial pressure is

The aquifer is assumed to be isotropic and the data sets that define properties in the "minimum" direction are linked to the data sets in the "maximum" direction so that all that needs to be done is set the default properties in the "maximum" direction.
